title: Jesse Reese
text:
Jesse Reese, was a black <a href="Communism">communist</a> and militant <a href="Union%20organizer">trade unionist</a> in the United States. 
Early life and career.
After being forced to work in a <a href="chain%20gang">chain gang</a>, Reese fled from Mississippi to <a href="Gary%2C%20Indiana">Gary</a>, <a href="Indiana">Indiana</a> in the 1920s. He likely joined the <a href="Communist%20Party%20USA">Communist Party</a> shortly after arriving. He lived with Walter Mackerl during the <a href="Great%20Depression">Great Depression</a>. The two of them knew each other from the <a href="Universal%20Negro%20Improvement%20Association%20and%20African%20Communities%20League">Universal Negro Improvement Association</a> and Reese was described as "a diehard" by Mackerl.
He got a job at <a href="Youngstown%20Sheet%20and%20Tube">Youngstown Sheet and Tube</a>, which was one of the "little steel" companies, in <a href="Indiana%20Harbor%20%28East%20Chicago%29">Indiana Harbor</a> in 1929. According to Reese, a Communist Party organizer came to his home, to ask him to become active in the <a href="Amalgamated%20Association%20of%20Iron%20and%20Steel%20Workers">Amalgamated Association</a> as his assignment. When he was warned that he would be confronted with <a href="Jim%20Crow%20laws">Jim crow</a>, Reese replied ""Well, I have a few other things on my mind. Freedom, <a href="Thomas%20Mooney">Tom Mooney</a>, the <a href="Scottsboro%20Boys">Scottsboro boys</a>–nine young Negro boys framed for rape in Scottsboro, Alabama."" 
Reese was one of the few openly black Communists and served as a spokesman for the party. Reese served as the president of the Youngstown Lake Front Lodge of the <a href="Amalgamated%20Association%20of%20Iron%20and%20Steel%20Workers">Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin workers</a>, before he became the first vice president of the newly formed Steel Worker Organizing Committee (SWOC) <a href="Local%20union">Local</a> 1011 in 1938.
In the 1930s Reese was named as one of the "six most active" union organizers for the Steel Workers Organizing Committee. In the summer of 1936, SWOC and <a href="National%20Negro%20Congress">National Negro Congress</a> held meetings 3 days a week, twice a day, corresponding with the shifts of the workers.
